en: Civilization of the Cherokees : [Excerpt] from an address of Honorable Edward Everett, representative in Congress from Massachusetts, delivered in the House of Representatives, 1830 May 19

This document is a typed excerpt from a speech delivered by Edward Everett, a Senator from Massachusetts, on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives on May 19, 1830. The speech was printed in the Congressional Debates, Vol. VI, pt. 2, and pertains to the proposed removal of the Southeastern Indians to a territory west of the Mississippi River. The typed excerpt presented here is from a portion of Everett's speech in which he describes the current conditions of the Cherokee people by enumerating statistics relative to population and property. This excerpt contains several minor variations from Everett's original wording.

none: Civilization of the Cherokees : [Excerpt] from an address of Honorable Edward Everett, representative in Congress from Massachusetts, delivered in the House of Representatives, 1830 May 19 : page 1

body.value: Civilization of the Cherokees . From an address of Honorable Edward Everett , representative in Congress from Massachusetts , delivered in the House of Representatives, May 19, 1830 . The census of the Cherokee Nation , East, for the year 1824 , shows 14,283 Cherokee citizens. They owned at this time 1,277 slaves. There were 18 schools in the Nation, with an attendance of 314 scholars of both sexes. They had 36 grist mills and 13 sawmills. There were 762 looms and 2,486 spinning wheels. They possessed 172 wagons and 2,923 plows. There were in the Nation 7,683 horses, 22,531 cattle, 46,732 swine, 2,566 sheep, 430 goats. There were 62 blacksmith shops, 9 stores, 2 tanyards tan-yards , and one powder mill.
